awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  A  Plasma Heat Engine for Efficient Production of Fusion Energy
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to produce a fusion-based engine in a system that is small, simple and inexpensive. The ultimate system will produce power that is as clean as renewable energy.  Since the system is small and has low radiation, it also has applications for manned space flight.  This new engine could enable more direct and shorter flights to other planets, which minimizes the exposure of astronauts to the radiation encountered in outer space.

This SBIR Phase II project proposes to continue the companies research on using a harmonic well to produce fusion by particle kinetic energy, rather than general thermal energy. The proposed concept utilizes a new heat engine technique that always maintains the plasma distribution function in thermodynamic equilibrium. In the proposed fusion system, a plasma is created in a specially designed harmonic well and then induced to form into two counter-oscillating spinning rings. When the two rings collide at the center of the well, the particle velocities are high enough to cause fusion.   This phase of the project will increase the energetics of the device. The project will move up to deuterium, a fuel which is twice as heavy as hydrogen (the current fuel) and has a much larger cross-section for fusion. The proposed approach is expected to make the harmonic well sufficiently energetic to produce deuterium-on-deuterium fusion by increasing the natural oscillation frequency of the well to give ion collision speeds of about one million meters per second. The project expects to be able to detect the neutrons produced by the fusion, demonstrating aneutronic fusion.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

NSF PHASE II OUTCOMES REPORT

The ultimate goal (of which this Phase II SBIR has been a second step) is to produce aneutronic fusion energy in a system that is small, simple and inexpensive.  The ultimate system will use an advanced fusion fuel (proton-Boron11) which does not produce neutrons or other penetrating radiation.

 

While there would be several applications for a small, environmentally green fusion reactor, one particular application of interest for such a system would be space propulsion and power generation for spacecraft. Chemical rocket systems are not well suited for space travel to Mars and beyond.  They are not powerful enough, and as a result travel time to Mars is a minimum 210 days in each direction. The result is that the astronauts are subjected to about 1.0 Sieverts of radiation for the trip.  This is the maximum amount of radiation that a worker is allowed in their entire lifetime, and may lead to radiation sickness. A small, environmentally green fusion reactor like our concept, would greatly shorten travel time, reducing the radiation dose and produce clean safe power for the spacecraft. (see Figure 1). 

 

The concept behind our fusion reactor is to have two spinning plasma rings that oscillate in the axial direction.  These rings are confined in an electro-magnetic potential created by a specially shaped magnetic and electric field. The two rings will collide with one another axially when both rings have their maximum axial velocities. Fusion will occur from the ring particles colliding at high relative velocities. This approach will allow for the use of advanced aneutronic fuels. (see Figure 2)

 

A previous NSF Phase I grant allowed us to build a proof-of concept experimental device called Shiner, and to obtain some encouraging results. The primary goal (and result) of the phase I work was to demonstrate that the desired electro-magnetic potential well could be formed and that an oscillating plasma ring could be maintained in the potential well.

 

The specific goal of this Phase II SBIR was to build a larger (not much) and more energetic (quite a bit) device called Acorn (see Figure 3) which could create fusion using Deuterium as fuel.

 

THE MAJOR OUTCOMES OF PHASE II HAVE BEEN:

A new experimental device Acorn, was designed and built, capable of producing kilo-Gauss magnetic fields and 40 KV electric fields. Acorn has a mid-line, radial view-port for additional plasma diagnostics such as a microwave plasma density interferometer.

A 10 Giga-Hertz microwave plasma density interferometer (see Figure 4) was designed, built, and tested but not yet applied to Acorn.

High-voltage experiments performed with Acorn demonstrated that shots as long as a hundred milli-seconds in duration can be taken at reasonable pressures using voltages up to 25 KV.

An excitation and control mechanism was built and tested which gave us some ability to stimulate and control the plasma oscillations. More work is needed to better understand and control the plasma response.

A small experimental diagnostic device (called mini-Acorn) was built out of spare parts which is of similar topology to Acorn, but is a fourth of the size. It has both axial and radial view ports for good visibility of the whole magnetic well, and uses a small plasma source (which we invented) to make a visible plasma and show the trajectory of the plasma as it falls into the well. This will aid us in understanding what is going on inside Shiner and Acorn.

 

Thanks to three years of NSF-funded work, we feel even more certain that our approach has merit and will be able to demonstrate Deuterium fusion with our Acorn device.
